two prisoners, with another person, standing at the door of a boot shop kept by Mr. Henderson—they were talking to each other—I saw two of them go inside the shop, when Fitzgerald closed up with the boots, took three pair of them, and put them under her shawl—she went about fifty yards up the street, when I overtook her—she was very obstinate—Green went away with the other person in the shop—I took Fitzgerald to the station.
Fitzgerald. Q. You did not see me take the boots, did you? A. Yes, you had the boots in your right hand, and placed them under your shawl—I was not five yards from you when you took them.

ANN PYLES . I am sister in law to Mr. Henderson. I was staying with my sister at the time the boots were taken—I know that the boots pro
duced belong to my brother in law because of the marks on them—I had seen them hanging at the door, and missed them afterwards—I saw two women come into the shop—one of them was Green—the other prisoner did not come into the shop—the woman who came in with the prisoner Green asked the price of goloshes—I told her 4s.—they then went out of the shop, and directly after I missed the boots, and the constable brought them to the shop.

Greens Defence. I never knew Fitzgerald till the Monday morning, when I met her and a young person who is living in London; I went with her to the shop to buy some goloshes; she said I can get them for 3s. 6d.; I turned round to beckon this other person, and she went out of the shop; as soon as I got to the door I saw a person I knew; all at once they mined these boots; I saw her again, and asked what she had done with the young woman, and she said, "She has taken a pair of boots, and is taken into custody"—when the boots were taken we were at the further end of one window, and the boots were at the other end.

GREEN—
NOT GUILTY .

FITZGERALD—
GUILTY . Aged 18—
Confined Six Months.

1058.
MARY GREEN was again indicted
for stealing 30 yards of printed cotton, value 18s.; the property of
Thomas Robinson Baker.
MR. DOYLE. conducted the Prosecution.

FREDERICK SIMMONS . I am in the employment of Mr. Baker, a linen-draper at Greensend, Woolwich. I saw the prisoner on Tuesday, 7th inst, at about 7 o'clock in the evening—I was at one corner of my master's shop, and the prisoner was at the other corner, and somebody with her—I saw her take a piece of print and put it in her shawl, and run across the road—I was outside the shop—I was looking at her through the window—I and another boy ran after her—the other boy got hold of her first, and I ran up afterwards—she saw us running after her, and she dropped the cotton—it was picked up by a little girl—I and the other boy brought the prisoner back to my master's shop, and he sent for a policeman—she said, "Let me go, there's good boys, it was not me that took it, it was another woman"—I have no doubt as to the woman that took it.

Prisoner's Defence. This person who was with me picked up a piece of print, and was pushing it under my shawl; being in drink I was frightened, and I ran away; I directly told the officer, when he took me into custody; I told him I thought he would find her at my son's house, or at the railway; the officer went, and found her at the railway; she was taken in labour and sent away to the union—he sent a young woman to ask me to go to the station to see the young woman; it appears she keeps young girls, and
gets her living by them; I was not aware what a character she was at the time.
GUILTY .
(The prisoner was further charged with having bun before convicted.)
JOHN NEWELL . (police sergeant, R). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction for stealing a pewter pot, having been before that convicted—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 45.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1059.
SUSAN ANN HABER
, stealing a medal and 9s.; the property of
Benjamin Bridges, from his person.

BENJAMIN BRIDGES . I live at No. 3, Bond-street, Commercial-road. On 27th Sept., I met the prisoner in the road near the railway station, at Deptford—she accosted me, and asked where I was going—I told her I was going home by the New Cross railway—she asked me for money—I went with her up some bye-lane—during the time I was with her, she put her hand in my pocket—I did not lie down with her—I was walking with her when I missed my money out of my pocket—I gave her a shilling—I had connection with her; then I found her hand in my pocket—I had in my pocket about nine shillings and a pocket piece along with them, in my right hand pocket—it was all taken away but a halfpenny—I had a fourpenny piece and two or three halfpence—I asked her for it—I said, "I will be satisfied if you give me half of it"—she denied having it—two young chaps came up—I do not know who they were—when I saw a policeman I gave her in charge—I had had a little to drink—I knew what I was about—I was not the worse for liquor.

AUBREY HAND . (policeman, 417). I was on duty at New Cross. I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor together—I heard them talking together very loud, and I went up to them—the prosecutor gave the prisoner in charge—she said she had not the money—she produced one shilling, and said that was all she had about her—she was taken to the station house and searched—the prosecutor had been drinking a little, but seemed to know what he was about.
ELIZABETH HOLMES . I am a searcher at the station house. I searched the prisoner, and found upon her a pocket piece and a fourpenny-piece—found them in her mouth.
BENJAMIN BRIDGES . re-examined. This is the pocket piece I had on the night in question.
NOT GUILTY .

1060.
SAMUEL WRIGHT
, stealing 12s. of
George Cowthard.

SARAH COWTHARD . I am the wife of George Cowthard, we keep a general shop. On the afternoon of Wednesday, the 8th instant, between 3 and 4 o'clock, I was sitting in my parlour adjoining the shop—I had my attention attracted to the ahop by the jingling of money, like silver—I went into the shop, and saw the prisoner with his hand in the till—he was leaning overihe counter, taking the money out of the till, and putting it into his pocket—he ran off with his hand in his pocket—he had money in his pocket—I had seen the till safe about two minutes before—there was then about twenty-five shillings in it—after he had gone away I found in it twelve shillings—I got my bonnet and ran after him—I am quite, con
tain the prisoner is the person—I saw him again the next day.

JOHN JAMES THOMASON . I live at Deptford. I was standing outside the prosecutor's door—I saw the prisoner run out of the shop—he had his hand in his pocket—I ran after him—I did not catch him—I am sure he is the person.
Prisoner's Defence. They accused me the next morning; I went down with the constable,. and the prosecutor said I was the person; I was at Woolwich all the time.

ALFRED JOHN CROUCH . (policeman, R 82). Nothing was found on him—he had a blue jacket on when he committed the robbery—the next morning he was dressed the same as he is now, in a blue smock—I asked him what he had done with his jacket—he said he had sold it—I have since found the jacket where he left it on the afternoon of this robbery.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1061.
PHILADELPHIA HOGBIN
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Margaret Taylor, with intent to do her grievous bodily harm.

MARGARET TAYLOR . I am the wife of Joseph Taylor, of No. 21, Francis-street, Woolwich, a private in the Marines. The prisoner lives in the same house—on the 11th of this month, I saw her in the passage; she was not sober—she seemed to know what she was about—she came to the top of the stairs, and abused me—I told her to go away, and she laid hold of me by the hair of my head—she had a knife, and she dragged me into the pas
sage with the knife in her hand, and stabbed file ui the face twice—it was a common dinner knife—I had not had any quarrel with her at that time—my husband and her husband had a little grievance, they had been before a Magistrate—when she bad hold of me, I cried out for assistance—she spoke about my husband before she struck me—she said Mr. Green had paid 1l. 2s., and that was a fine thing out of a private's pay—she cut me in my neck, and underneath my eye—Mr. Bull came and tried to take the knife from her.
Prisoner. Q. You did not go into Bull's room, and take the chamber convenience and throw at me, did you? A. I never went into Bull's room at all.

GEORGE BULL . I was in the house, and heard a cry for assistance—I went up stairs, and found Mrs. Taylor and Mrs. Hogbin; Mrs. Hoghin had a knife in her hand—the handle of it was bloody, and Mrs. Taylor was bleeding—I tried to take the knife from her, and she said she would stab me too.

Prisoner. Q. You were in your room with your wife when Mrs. Taylor went into your room and took the chamber utensil from under your bed; it was a yellow one, was it not? A. I was in my room, but Mrs. Taylor never came into my room—she did not take it from my room and throw at you—I never saw her throw anything; it was not taken from my room.

ELIZABETH SMITH . I was at the prosecutrix's house on the night in question—I heard some words, and Mrs. Taylor hallooed out for help—I went in the passage, and saw Mrs. Taylor and Mrs. Hoghin both together—Mrs. Taylor was undermost—the prisoner had a knife in her hand, and when I pulled her off she made a stab at me, and stabbed me—I never had any quarrel with her—I was assisting her as well as Mrs. Taylor.

CHARLES CARTWRIGHT . (policeman, R 384). I took the prisoner into cus
tody—the prosecutrix's face was cut on the left side—it was not a bad cut—there were twe places cut—the prisoner seemed to me to be sober; her face was cut also—it appeared as though it had been scratched with some thing.
ELIZABETH SMITH . re-examined. I did not see how the prisoner's face was hurt; not without she got a scratch when she fell down in the passage.
FELIX NEWTON . I heard a noise in the passage, and heard a woman cry
out—I saw Mrs. Taylor standing against the front door, trying to keep the prisoner off—I went round the back way, and got to her—I took the knife from her—I did not take notice of any blood upon it.

WILLIAM HART . I wish to speak a few words for my daughter, the prisoner. I knew there was a quarrel in the house, and I heard the screams of my daughter while she was attacked—I could not render her any anist
ince—(the witness had lost both his arms)—I was that my daughter's face was cut and bruised in a moat desperate way on the left aide, as if she had been pushed against the floor, or the railings—she went down to get a sammons for the ill usage ahe had had, when the other peaty was there—my son-in-law took out the summons.

MRS. HART. I am the mother of the prisoner. I happened to put my head through my front window, and I saw a mob collected—I saw my daughter on the steps, with a knife in her hand—I do not wonder at my daughter being exasperated—there were eighteen or twenty non-com
missioned officers and marines standing round—Mm. Taylor was sitting on the stairs, with my daughter's head in her lap—Mrs. Taylor opened the front parlour door, and dragged her out.

CHARLES CARTWRIGHT . recalled. They all earae down to the station to
gether—I did not at any time see the prosecutrix pulling the prisoner by the hair of her head—the prosecutrix's face was out from the cheek bone to the ear, scratched—I have known the prosecatrix and the prisoner for a considerable time—I have known them both to he the worse for liquor at times, but never to be so as to be under the interference of the police—the prisoner is a well conducted person generally—I have never known them to be quarrelling together—when the prisoner came down to the station house ihe appeared to be perfectly sober.

Prisoners Defence. Because I wished to keep myself to myself, the prose
eutrix was irritated against me and my husband; the party she has got against me were all drinking together, and, because I do not do the same, I am one of the vilest of the vile; ray husband had occasion to bring her to tat court on the 5th of last month, and she mid, if it might be twenty years, she would have it out, and she would lie in wait for me; on 18th Oct she said she would pay somebody to lie in wait for us.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Months.

1062.
JOHANNA KEEFE
, stealing 17s.; the moneys of
Sarah Wane, from her person.
MR. DOYLE. conducted ike Prosecution.

SARAH WANE . I am a 'widow, and live in Canon-row, Woolwich. on Saturday evening, I life Oct., between 7 and 8 o'clock, I was out marketing—I went to Mr. Hughes's shop, and bought some butter—I then counted my money—I had 18s.—I paid 1s. for the cotter, and had 17s., and a farthing remaining—I then went across to Mr. Aland's shop, and looked at a breast of mutton, but did not buy anything—the prisoner followed me from Mr. Hughes's to Mr. Bland's, and was at my left side some time—ahe Aifted to my back—I went to put my hand to my pocket, and her hand was in my pocket—I tried to hold it, but, being paralyzed on that side,'lost my grasp, and she ran out—I tben missed my mony from my right pocket—there was no other person near me behind; I stoed at the baek of the persons at the Counter—I followed the prisoner over into Mr. Hughes's again eanght hold of her, and said, "You wretch, you have robbed me; give me my money"—I took her into Mr. Bland's shop again, and a police
man searched her—not having much use in my hand, it down on he
side of my pocket, and I know that my money was safe up to the time her hand got there—her hand was shut; I could not keep it in my pocket; I have no power.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Is Hughes's shop a little distance from the butcher's? A. Just across the road, a very little slanting—there were a good many people in the butcher's; it was Saturday night, at 7 or 8 o'clock—she was at the side of me; that was the reason that I accused her—she followed close behind me from Mr. Hughes's—I was ten minutes in the butcher's shop, during which time people came in and out, but they had not to pass where I stood—I saw Rebecca Cooper directly I went out, and I saw the prisoner then; I could see her all the time—nobody would help me—I asked Mr. Bland, but he said that he could not leave his busi
ness—the money was four half crowns, six shillings, two sixpences, and a farthing—the prisoner heard what I said to Mr. Bland, and ran out directly—I charged her with robbing me before she ran.

REBECCA COOPER . I am the wife of William Cooper, of Queen-street, Woolwich. I was standing outside Mr. Hughes's door, waiting for my laughter, and saw the prisoner come across the road in a hurried manner, as if she had been doing something wrong—she did not run, but she hurried—she went to the middle of Mr. Hughes's shop, with a shawl over her arm—Mrs. Wane came in, and said, "You have robbed me of all my money, 17s. and a farthing"—the prisoner said nothing—I said, "Hold her fast; do not let her go"—she turned round and said, "I am not afraid; I can stand to my tack"—I afterwards saw her in custody.
Cross-examined. Q. When she was first charged, did not she say, "Go along with you, I have not robbed you"? A. Yes—it is a very busy place, like a market place.

WILLIAM WILKINSON . (policeman, R 237). On Saturday evening, 11th Oct., the prisoner was given into my custody by Mrs. Wane—she denied the charge—I asked her to produce her pocket, and found in it 6 1/2 d. in copper, and a yellow return ticket to London from Woolwich, of that date, Oct. 11th—she was searched at the station, and nothing was found upon her—I asked her what she came to Woolwich for—she said, "To see a friend"—I asked her if she could find him—she said that she did not know where—I asked where he worked—she said, "At some stonemason's yard"—she did not give his name—Woolwich is much more crowded than London streets on Saturday nights—she gave her address in Leman-court, Leman-street, Whitechapel—I went there, and she had lived there last May.

JURY. to REBECCA COOPER. Q. How long elapsed from the time of its being taken and the prisoner being given in charge? A. It was more than ten minutes before we could get a policeman—we held her all the time.
NOT GUILTY .

1063.
DAVID HARPLEY and
WILLIAM MAUGHAN
(marines), burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Matthew Marks, at Woolwich, and stealing therein 60 yards of lace, 1 pair of epaulettes, and other articles, value 15l.; his goods.—2nd COUNT, feloniously receiving the same.
MR. O'CONNELL. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES PENTON . I live at Sandy-hill, Plumstead. On Saturday, 1st Oct., I was going home from Woolwich theatre, between 12 o'clock and half past, and saw two marines in uniform, standing near Mr. Marks' premises, one tall and one short—the tall man was dark, I could see his face—they were looking towards the public house, not towards Marks'—they were about the height of the two prisoners, but I cannot swear to them.

JOHN MALONEY . I am a bombardier and collar maker in the Royal Artillery. On Wednesday morning, 15th Oct, about half past 6 o'clock, I passed by Mr. Marks' place, and saw the window half open, and a quantity of lace and a civilian's cloth cap on the cill outside—there was a hole cut in the double panel of the shutter, to admit the fingers of a man to ease the bolt—I put the cap on the area, pushed the lace in, and called Mr. Marks up—the lace seemed as if a person had dropped it or pulled it in coming out of the window—any man could have got in at the window, it was half open—a pane of glass was broken close to the catch, so that they could put their hand in and open the window, and get in.

PHILIP HART . I am a general dealer, of Artillery-place, Woolwich. On Wednesday morning, 15th Oct, about 11 o'clock, Harpley brought me a piece of new lace—I bought it of him for 8d., and he went away—about 2 o'clock both the prisoners came with some gold lace in a handkerchief—I asked them where it came from—they said, "Wait, and we will show you"—they gave me a push against the counter, and went away, one to the right and one to the left—I went after them, but could not catch them—I took the lace to the station house—my shop is 150 yards from Mr. Marks'—this is the lace (produced).

NATHAN MARKS . I am a general dealer, of Mount-street, Bull-fields, in the parish of Woolwich, it is my dwelling house. On Tuesday night, 14th Oct, I went to bed at 11 o'clock, the doors and windows were all fast—an artilleryman called me up next morning, about half past 6 o'clock, and I found the shutters hanging open, and the widow open, it was broken, and the catch turned back—I missed a great quantity of lace and a pair of epau
lettes—I can hardly tell how much lace I missed, as I buy a great deal; and it was mostly in the window—sixty or seventy yards were gone, and perhaps more—I do not weigh it, because I buy it on officers' coats—I also missed an officer's sword and tassels, a concertina, a silver mounted flute, and a cap, but the cap was found—this (produced) is my lace—the value of what I last was 12l. or 15l.

JAMES HADRILL . I am sergeant major of the Royal Marines. Both the prisoners belong to my corps—on Tuesday night, 14th Oct, they were both out on leave—Maughan has been back since the depositions were taken, but Harpley has not—I saw them at the police court—Harpley was in uniform, Maughan was not.

JAMES WESTBROOK . (policeman, R 114). I apprehended Harpley in a house in Warner-lane, Woolwich—sergeant Newell was with me—we found him in a back room, with a female—I told him I wanted to take him to Artillery-place, to see whether he was the right man—he said, "I am willing to go with you, but I know I am not the man"—it was between 10 and 11 o'clock—he put his clothes on, and I said, You were at a Jew's shop in Artillery-place yesterday"—he said, "Oh! I know what lair you have got me on now"—he said that he was in Jack's canteen yesterday morning, and another marine gave him a piece of lace to sell for 8d., which he did, and that he went again with him, and he had something in a hand-kerchief, but he did not know what it was—on the 18th I saw Maughan at Charlton fair, and supposing him to be a deserter, I asked him if he did not belong to the Royal Marines—he said, "No," and that his name was Wil
liam Jones—I told him I should take him on suspicion of being a deserter, and also of committing a robbery at Woolwich—he said that he was not the man—I looked at his shirt, saw the name of Maughan on it, and de
tained him—I found this large knite and purse on him (produced).

JOHN NEWELL . (police sergeant, R 59). I was with Wertbrook, and found Harpley in the room—we ascertained that he was staying with a female, who is the sister of the other prisoner—she said so to us—I found a knife over the fire place, and aaked him whether it was his—he said yes, and that he had found it the night before last (I afterwards fitted it to the putty of the glass)—I asked him in Maughan's presence if he was the man who gave Manghan the lace to sell—he said "Yes"—I asked him if he was the one who went to the selling the second time with him, and he said "Yes"—Maughan heard it, but said nothing—I examined the shutters; from the size of the hole I should say that it would take full an hour to cut—they would have to reach over the area steps to cut it—they could not stand upon the railings; they would be too high—they might have stood on the railings to break the glass by the catch.

JURY. to NATHAN MARKS. Q. Do you swear to the lace? A. Yes—you could not get a piece in any shop in Woolwich like this, which was sold for 8d.—it was in my window—nothing was taken from the glass case in my shop—the concertina, flute, and cap were all in the window, and they opened it and took them—this piece of lace is the collar of a sergeant of artillery—I know it well—it was hanging on the concertina—I can also swear to this copper lace—I have had it two years, and the rest twelve weeks—this other is not lace; it is used to go inside epaulettes, and I took it out.

Harpley. There was a set of beads taken from my neck, which the prose
cutor swore to, add afterwards he said that they were not his. Witness. I never swore to them—I had such hanging in my window, and missed them; the string was broken—I believe these to be them (looking at them).
JOHN NEWELL , re-examined. Harpley was wearing these beads round his neck, under his clothes.
Harpley's Defence. The articles I sold were given to me.

HARPLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

MAUGHAN/—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

1064.
MARTHA BRINFIELD
, feloniously setting fire to the dwelling house of
John Brinfield, with intent to injure
Henry Alfred Collington.
MR. SERJEANT PARRY. and MR. SIMON. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLOTTE MONDAY . I am a widow, and live at No. 3, Bennett's-gardens, Greenwich. On Saturday night, 20th Sept., about half-past 8 o'clock, I dis
covered the smell of fire—I searched my own premises to see if there was anything to account for it—I found nothing—I then went out—I returned about half-past 9 o'clock, and found the street all in confusion—I did not see anything of the fire.

HARRIET HODGES . I am married. I live at No. 1, Bennett-street, East Greenwich—the prisoner occupies the next door, No. 2—the house are separated by a passage—there is a loft over her house—the passage was kept locked, and I kept the key—it leads from the street to my back kitchen—no one could have access to the passage without my knowing it—about three weeks or a month before 20th Sept., the prisoner told me that she owed Mrs. Collington some rent, and she wanted to get her out; would I allow her to put a few things in the passage, in case Mrs. Collington should put any person in her house—I unlocked the door, and told her she could put in anything—I afterwards saw some things there, but did not examine them—the prisoner brought me the key again in the course of the day—I ascertained that the

door was properly locked—on the Saturday before the fire I had occasion to go through the passage—I locked the door then, and I am sure it was not unlocked again until the next Saturday, which was the day the fire occurred—I had possession of the key during the whole of that time—the prisoner's boy was assisting me on the Saturday in carrying out coals—he was with me the whole of that day—I saw the prisoner several times that day—I am not aware that there was any communication between her premises and the passage—about 9 o'clock that evening I heard the alarm of fire.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Is there a mode by which persons can get from the passage into the shop? A. If they had a ladder, or some
thing that they could reach by—there is no trap-door—the passage is not finished; the wall has never been carried up—there is nothing to prevent any person getting from the ground up to the loft when once in the passage—I am not aware of any other way of getting to the loft—I kept the key of the passage on the top of the clock in my room—it was there at the time of the fire.

CHARLES MOORE . I am a beer shop keeper, in Bennett-street, Green-wich. On Saturday, 20th Sept, about half past 9 o'clock, in consequence of what my little girl said, I went across the road to the prisoner's house—I went into the front parlour; there were three or four persons there—I said, "There is a fire here, let us have a light"—they had no candle, but they had a fire—by that time constable 74 came in—I said, "Get me a candle, and we will see where this fire is"—I got a candle and went up stairs into the front room—there was nothing at all in that room, with the exception of a few rags lying on the further side of the room, towards the front of the house—I said to the constable, "Here is no fire here"—I went across the room, and opened a cupboard door—I found two bricks had been removed from the bottom part of the cupboard, and I was the flames raging behind the wall that parts the bedroom from the loft—the removal of those bricks would enable a person to put rags, or anything, into the loft—I found some rags there—I had to cut the partition down and throw some pails of water through to stay the fire, and then I went into the loft where the fire was—I found something like half a bushel of rags and paper, and a butter firkin all burning together; that part which was towards the passage was not burned, but all round towards the hole was burned—part of the joists of the kitchen ceiling were burned—the flame was raging about two or three feet high when I first saw it; the joists were burning—a surveyor who has seen the house has given me orders to put in two new joists, on account of those being so burnt—if the fire had not been put out then, in my opinion it would have spread in less than ten minutes, and the whole row of houses would have been burnt down—amongst the rags there was some whitey brown paper, and some pieces of blue cotton shirting—I believe they cor
responded with some of the rags found in the room—I know the situation of this loft; the only mode of reaching it from the prisoner's premises was by the hole that was cut through the brick wall of the cupboard—I saw the prisoner after the fire had been put out; I met her about twenty yards from the house—she said, "Mr. Moore, they tell me my house is on fire"—I said, "No, don't frighten yourself, it is not on fire, it is put out;" and she turned on her heel, and said, "Well, I will go and let them see if anybody is there;" and she went to the door—whether she attempted to knock at the door, or whether she forced it open, I cannot say, but she was falling to the ground, and policeman, No. 74, caught hold of her arm, and picked her up—I think she had been drinking a little.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you take the trouble to measure exactly where-abouts in the wall this hole was? A. No, I did not—I suppose it was a four inch wall—the hole was nearly on a level with the floor; it might be three inches and a half below the level of the cupboard—I did not take notice—a communication could have been made with the loft by knocking out one brick; the top brick was what we term a bat, that is, half a brick, or a three-quarter brick—there was about a half sieve basket among the rags, and a butter firkin; none of that was my property—I do not know whe
ther any of it belonged to Mr. Hodges—the prisoner's three children were at this very time in the house, sitting by the fire in the front parlour—when I met the prisoner, and spoke to her about the fire, she said she would go and see who was there, or something to that effect—I do not think I mis
took excitement for the effect of drink; I am quite certain of that.
MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. Were there other persons in the house besides the children? A. Yes; three or four persons were in the front room.

CHARLES FORWARD . (policeman, R 74). On the night of 20th Sept., I was at my own house, at Greenwich. I discovered the appearance of fire, and went into Mr. Brinfield's house, No. 2, Bennett-street, where it was raging—Mr. Moore went with me; we went up stairs together—about six or seven pails of water were used to extinguish the fire—I gave Mr. Moore two upstairs, which he threw on—a hammer was fetched, and while he was using it to make a hole, I threw on three or four more pails—I saw the bricks which had been displaced; it appeared to have been recently done—as I was going up the stairs I saw a crack in the lath and plaster wall, and through that crack I could see the fire burning distinctly—the hole in the cupboard was apparently made from the cupboard into the loft; the hole appeared to be made at the bottom of the cupboard; the bricks appeared to have been driven through into the place where the rags and paper was burning—my brother constable has the bricks, which he found afterwards and fitted—I saw some mortar in the loft, which appeared as if it had been forced through.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe this poor woman and her children were in a state of wretched poverty? A. They were, there was no furniture in the upstairs room.

JOHN TESTER . (policeman, R 89). I took the prisoner into custody on 20th Sept. Before doing so, I examined the hole in the wall—it was on a level with the floor of the cupboard—the first brick was placed on the floor, and the other over it—they were both above the level of the floor—in my judgment, the hole was made from the cupboard into the loft, by the way in which the bricks fitted the hole—there is a notch on the brick, showing that it was punched out from the cupboard side (producing the bricks)—I fitted the bricks so as to tell in what way they were placed—I took possession of some of the rags that were left unburnt, and produce them—among them is a piece of blue shirting—I also produce some rags which I found in the room—there is some blue shirting amongst that, which corresponds with that found in the loft—it was about 11 o'clock when I saw the prisoner—she was intoxicated.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you tell her that you took her into custody on suspicion of having set fire to her house? A. Yes—she denied it—she said, "My God, me set fire to my house, and my children in it!"—I picked up these two bricks—they had fallen from the hole down into the passage leading from the street to Mrs. Hodges's back kitchen—there was a large hole in the ceiling where some one had apparently broken through in Put
ting out the fire; the bricks were lying in the passage directly under the

hole, and the bricks were knocked from the cupboard on to the ceiling, and might have fallen from there, or been knocked off in putting the fire out—the fire was about seven or eight inches from the wall.

CHARLES MAYO TALMADGE . I reside at Greenwich, and am agent to the Globe Insurance Company. On the night of 20th Sept., in consequence of a communication made to me, I went to examine these premises—Mr. Moore showed me the cupboard—I took the candle, looked into it, and well examined the wall—I found that the bricks had evidently been removed very recently—we then went on to the stairs, and through the hole he had made into the loft—I took from there a portion of the remaining fragments of rags—a good portion of the paper and rags had been burnt, about one third of it—I produce what I found—there is a piece of striped shirting amongst it—it is a very common pattern at Greenwich—I afterwards went into the passage that divides the two houses—I there found some bricks lying down in the passage—any person putting their hand through the hole in the cupboard could throw the bricks below, or they might have fallen from the blow which thrust them out.
Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner is not insured? A. No—I do not know whether Hodges is.

SARAH WILSON . I am married, and live at No. 6, Bennet-street, Wool-wich. I know the prisoner—I saw her on the Saturday, the day of the fire, several times—between 3 and 4 o'clock I picked up a pewter pot in front of her house, and took it over to a beer shop opposite Mr. Moore's—she said that the b——old b——had been after the rent, and she would see her in flames before she would pay it, for anybody that paid rent was fools; for six months and a fortnight she could keep her house, and then she would set fire to the b——building, and if the old b——came by, she would take and throw her b——carcase into the flames—she was perfectly comfortable when she said this—I mean she was not intoxicated—I do not think she had been drinking—about a month or six weeks before that she said the old b—had been after the rent, and she would not pay any, she would see her at—first—she had better put the money on the clothes—her husband had taken a house, and she had refused the key, she was not going to be such a b——fool as to take another house until she had done her work—we had not been drinking together on the day in question—we were on friendly terms, so far as neighbours, only good morning and good night, never holding any conversation, only when she thrust her conversation in like that.

Cross-examined. Q. You were not always on very friendly terms? A. I do not know of anything to the contrary—I never had an angry word with her—I know Mr. Mayberry by sight—I never had a quarrel with the prisoner (Mayberry was here called in)—I never said that I would do any
thing I could to spite and injure the prisoner—I never said that to Mayberry at the police court—Miss Moore was in and out from the yard to the bar while the prisoner was saying this to me—she did not hear what passed.

ISABELLA COLLLNGTON . The house in question belongs to my son, Henry Alfred Collington. The prisoner has paid two weeks' rent, and she owes twenty-four next Monday—I have applied to her for rent two or three times every week—I had not applied to her on 2nd Sept.—I had the Saturday before.
NOT GUILTY .

1065.
EDWARD VENICE and
CATHERINE MOREAN were in
dicted for
unlawfully having counterfeit coin in their possession, to which

VENICE
PLEADED GUILTY . * Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.

MOREAN
PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Nine Months.

1066.
ANN SULLIVAN was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MR. W. J. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

EMILY ADDYLEZAR SAUNDERS . I am barmaid at a tavern in Union-street, Southwark. On 15th Sept. the prisoner came there about half past 3 o'clock for a pint of porter—she gave me a shilling—I kept it in my hand, bent it, and said it was bad—she said, "I got it from a lady at Blackheath"—she wanted it back, but I would not give it to her—she went away, and did not pay for the beer—I laid the shilling on a back shelf, under a wine glass—I afterwards gave it to David Morris.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not give it to a lady at the bottom of the counter? A. No, I never moved—I did not lose sight of it.
Prisoner. It was a King William shilling; she gave me the change before she said it was bad.

HENRY LEESON . I am barman at the Henry the Eighth, in Union-street. On 15th Sept. the prisoner came about a quarter before 4 o'clock—she asked for a pint of porter—she paid me a bad shilling—I told her it was bad, and bent it on the counter—she said she did not know it was bad, it was all the money she had about her, and she got it in Blackfriars-road—I gave her into custody, and gave the shilling to Morris.
MARY ANN MORRIS . I am the widow of David Morris (policeman, M 49)—he died 15th Oct.—this is his writing to this deposition.

HENRY LEESON . re-examined. I heard Morris examined before the Magistrate—his deposition was taken in the room, and read before the Magistrate—he said that it was true, in the prisoner's presence, and she was asked if she had any question to put to him—she said, "No."

The deposition was here read as follows: "David Morris saith, I am a police constable, M 49—I took the prisoner into custody at the Henry the Eighth, in Union-street—I received this counterfeit shilling at the time—I also received from the first witness a counterfeit shilling which I also produce."
MARY ANN MORRIS . re-examined. My husband brought home two shillings wrapped in paper, and gave them to me to take care of—after his death I gave them to his brother to take to the station.
ROBERT MORRIS . Mary Ann Morris gave me two shillings in a paper—I took them to the police station, and gave them to sergeant Davis.
WILLIAM DAVIS . (police sergeant, M 15). I received these two shilling from the last witness.
HENRY LEESON . re-examined. This is the shilling I took from the prisoner—I marked it at the station, and know it again.
EMILY ADDYLEZAR SAUNDERS . re-examined. This is the shilling I took of her—I marked it at the station.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint—these are both bad.
Prisoner's Defence. She took the shilling to the bottom of the counter;
she came back and took the change out of my hand; I told the lady where I took it, and told the Magistrate the same; I am sure that that shilling was not the shilling I gave her.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Nine Months.

1067.
CHARLES CHAMBERS
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Matthew Jones on his head, with intent to kill and murder him.—2nd COUNT, to do him grievous bodily harm.
MR. ROBINSON. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM CHURCH . I am taskmaster at the workhouse of St. Mary, Lambeth. I know the prisoner perfectly well—he has been in and out of the house during the time I have been there, about nine months—on the morning of 27th Sept. I went to the place where the prisoner slept about half past 5 o'clock—he was in bed—I told him to get up—he said he should not get up then—I visited him again about half an hour afterwards—I again found him in bed, and told him to get up—he said he would see me b—first—I visited him a third time, about 8 o'clock, I think—he still persisted that he would not get up, and made use of bad language—I told him I should call the attention of the master to it, which I did—Mr. Jones, the assistant master, and myself then went to him, and we pulled the clothes off him—with that he got on to the ground with his feet—he was sitting, and he rose up and struck Mr. Jones on the chest with his foot—he made use of bad language and swearing—I do not recollect what—he ordered Mr. Jones out of the room—Mr. Jones refused to go, and he said, "You b——, if you don't go, I have got something here will make you"—with that he went to a bed in the further end of the room, and drew from under the bed this bar of iron, and he came back, and gave a slashing cut with it towards Mr. Jones's head—it was a violent blow, and I saw the blood flow immediately afterwards—Mr. Jones did not strike him from first to last, but after he struck, Mr. Jones closed in with him, and I took the bar from him—this is a protection bar of the window guard—I had seen it in its proper place about 7 o'clock the evening before—it was attached to the window—it had been fastened with screws, and it had been unscrewed—this is only half the bar—the other half was under the bed—when I saw it the evening before, it was one long bar attached to the window—I cannot say that I had ever heard the prisoner use any threats towards Mr. Jones—he was a man that used very violent language—he was placed in that ward by order of the guardians, the night before, for his misconduct—it is not a worse ward than the others, only they do more labour in it—it is a ward for casual paupers—the whole of the inmates of the workhouse got up at half past 5 o'clock at that time—Mr. Jones did not strike the prisoner from first to last—till he had been struck by the bar, he did not lay hand on him—I did not touch him till I took the iron out of his hand—neither Mr. Jones nor I had any bludgeon or staff, or anything in our hands—neither of us threatened to strike him.

MATTHEW JONES . I am assistant master of Lambeth workhouse. On 27th Sept., my attention was called to the prisoner by Mr. Church—I went at about a quarter before 9 o'clock, and found him in bed—I told him to get up and go to his work the same as the other inmates—we had then about 940 in the house—he said, "I will see you b——first"—we caught hold of the clothes, and took them off him—directly he was out of bed he made a blow at my neck—I kept him off—he struck me with his foot, and

said, "Go out of the ward"—I declined going out, and he stepped back from the bed he was on, about two or three paces, and said, "I have got some
thing here for you"—he stepped back to another bed, and said, "You b——, I have got something here for you"—he took this iron from under the bed, and came up to me with full force with the iron—I parried it off as well as I could, but it just caught my forehead—he struck me a violent blow—I caught some of it on my arm—the cut was just over my eye; the blood came all down about the room—I was attended by the surgeon—I was confined a fortnight, or close upon it—I was not fit for duty for some time—I did not strike him at all—I pushed him off when he struck me—I did not strike him, to call striking—I pushed him away when he struck me in the face—I warded off the blow—after he struck me I closed with him, and Church took the iron out of his hand—I had him secured—he was given into custody, and taken before a magistrate the same day.
Prisoner. You came to me at half-past 9 o'clock, and pulled me out of bed by the leg, and struck me with your fist Witness. I did not strike you a blow at all; I never touched you, only the clothes.

COURT. Q. How long has he been in the workhouse? A. I have known him to be there, on and off, for three years—he was not there for sickness—he is an able bodied man, but we are obliged to take persons who are willing to come into the house.

HENRY MEAKIN . (policeman, L 143). I was called into the workhouse between 8 and 9 o'clock, on 27th Sept., and the prisoner was given into my custody—going to the station, he told me that Mr. Jones asked him to fight, and he struck him across the forehead, over the eye—he afterwards said, Mr. Jones had struck him before he struck Mr. Jones.
Prisoner. Did I say I struck him with the iron? Witness. No; you said you struck him across the forehead.

HENRY ST. JOHN BULLEN . I live in Kennington-place, and am surgeon of Lambeth workhouse. I was called in to see Mr. Jones—before that my assistant had placed some slight dressing on his head, which I removed—I found a small wound on his head, about half an inch in length—I con
sidered it an incised wound—there was slight contusion round the edges—it extended to the bone—it was just over the left temple against the eye—I have continued to attend him ever since—he did favourably, so far as the wound was considered, but his nervous system received a severe shock.

COURT. Q. It was not a wound, I suppose, necessarily dangerous unless erysipelas had come on? A. Unless inflammatory symptoms had come on, or erysipelas, there was no danger—I attributed the nervous shock to pro
ceed from the affection of the brain, in consequence of the blow.

Prisoners Defence. I did not strike him with the bar; he tucked up his things, and challenged me to fight; I took up the bar in my own defence; about half-past 10 o'clock at night the master ordered me to the casual ward on bread and water; that morning the taskmaster came and told me to get up; I said I was not able; he called Mr. Jones, and he came and struck me under the mouth; I said, "If you strike me again, I will hit you"—I told him to get out, and he would not; I was removed from one ward to another; I was brought up as a witness against Mr. Jones before the Commissioners, and I have been put upon ever since; he said he should like to give me four years; I knocked, the master's head against the iron bedstead; he had kept me forty-eight hours without food.
COURT. to MR. JONES. Q. Are there any iron bedsteads there? A. They are all iron bedsteads—I was not knocked against a bedstead—there was
an inquiry, but he was not a witness against me—there was a complaint against an officer of the house, but I was not there—I was complimented for doing my duty.
JUBY. Q. Did you keep the prisoner forty-eight hours without food? A. No; we did not; we were obliged to put him in that ward because he wag a very bad character; we did not know what to do with him.

COURT. to MR. BULLEN. Q. Was the prisoner unable to work? A. Not at that time—he fractured his collar bone about three months ago, but he was able to work at that time, at the work he was put to, which was picking oakum—he was released from hard labour by my direction.

GUILTY. * on Second Count. Aged 22.—
Four Years Penal Servitude

1068.
JOSEPH SMALL
. feloniously uttering two 5l. notes, with intent to defraud.
MESSRS GIFFARD. and BAILEY. conducted the Prosecution.

EMILY PALMER . I live with my uncle, a dairyman, at Camberwell, the prisoner is a tenant of my uncle's. On Wednesday, 1st Oct., lie came and asked me if I would take 12s. for two weeks' rent, and give him the change for a 5l. note—I took the note, and I noticed two names on it—this is the note—here is the name of Thomas Taylor on it—I asked the prisoner to write his name, and he did so—I took 12s., and gave him 4l. 8s.—I passed the note away in the course of business, and it was returned as forged—on Saturday, 4th Oct., the prisoner came again about half-past 9 o'clock—he had a note in his hand, and he asked me if I would give him change for it—I took it, and looked at it—I said, "It appears to be a good one"—he said, "I hope it is, I had it from my father in the country—I returned it to him, and said that I had not enough change—he asked me if I would send over to the Waterloo Arms to get it changed for him, as he was a stranger there, and the people did not like changing a note for him—I said, "I should think any of the houses you are in the habit of using would change it for you"—he then asked me if I would give him 4l., and give his wife the remainder on Monday morning—I told him I could not do it—I did not send him for change on that or any other day.

Cross-examined by MR. METTCALFE. Q. You hare collected the prisoner's nut for some time for your uncle? A. Yes; the prisoner has been living there about two years—not a quarter of a mile from us—I knew him well, and he knew me—I did not see him very often—I received the rent from his wife generally—it is a private house where I live.

JANE LEWTY , jun. My father keeps the Waterloo Arms, at Gamberwell On Saturday afternoon, 4th Oct., the prisoner came—I was standing at the bar—he said, "Can you give me change for a 5l. note, for Miss Palmer; I wish to pay her some money, and she has only change sufficient to pay the men"—I took the note to my mother, in the bar parlour—she gave it me back, and told me to give change for it—I gave the prisoner four sovereigns and 1l. worth of silver—I gave him a pen and ink, and told him to write his name on the note, and he did so—he asked if he should write his address—I said, "Yes, if you please"—he did so—this is the note—in the course of the next week it was returned as forged.

Cross-examined. Q. In consequence of this address you went to him and found him? A. Yes; my brother found the note was forged, and the pri
soner came to our house on the Sunday.
JANE LEWTY . I am the mother of the last witness. I received a 5l. note from her oh that Saturday—I took it upstairs—I brought it back, and gave it to her.

BENNETT LEWTT . I am the son of the last witness. On Sunday, 12th Oct., in consequence of the note being returned, I went to the address on the note, to No. 11, Acorn-street, between 7 and 8 o'clock in the evening—the prisoner was in bed—I stood outside for a minute or two, and the pri
soner came out—I asked him to walk to our house with me—he had no jacket or boots on—he went back and put them on, and came out with them—he came to our bar parlour—the note laid on the table in such a position that he could see it—I told him that the note that my sister had changed for him had come back from the bankers, and they believed it was forged—he said, "Is it? I was not aware of it; I suppose I must get you the money"—I asked him where he got it from—he said, "I don't think I am bound to tell you"—I told him he had better, or it would be a very bad job for us both, and cause a great deal of trouble—he said, "I will tell you then; I found two of them in a brass-bound ports monnaie, in the Borough, and I gave the other to my landlord"—I said, "Did you?"—I then said I would go to the Bank in the morning, and if it was a forgery I would come down to his house—he said, "Very well"—I went to his home the next day, about half-past 2 o'clock—I had then been to the Bank, and found the note was forged—when I got to the house the door was shut—I did not see the prisoner—I saw the lodger—I believe the prisoner has a wife; I did not see her—I went to the Peckham police station, and gave information to sergeant Bond—on Thursday, 16th Oct, I went with ser
geant Bond to No. 9, York-terrace, Peckham, and found the prisoner there with two children.

Cross-examined. Q. In what part of Camberwell is Acorn-street? A. About a quarter of a mile from, the Green—the prisoner did not tell me that he picked them up on 19th Sept.—he said that he waited for some time to see if they would be advertised for, and that he took them to some tradesman, whose name he mentioned, to see if they were good—I cannot recollect that he told me that there was a shilling and a sixpence in the porte monnaie besides the notes—when I went to his house, I did not tell him what I wanted him for, till he came to our bar parlour, and he walked in with me, and looked at the note—he did not say that he must go in the country to get the money—he said he would try and get it—he said after
wards that he had been to a friend of his in the country to try to get it.

Q. Did he and his wife both tell you that they had been trying to raise the 5l. and if you had not given them into custody at that time, they should have raised the money? A. I have no recollection of his saying that—he told me that he had been to a friend, who had promised to advance it for him, and he should have raised it if I had not taken him—he said that he had been in the country to his father.

JOHN BOND . (police sergeant, S 26). I went with the last witness to Acorn-street, on Monday, 13th Oct, I went there on several subsequent occa
sions—I did not find the prisoner on any occasion—on 16th, I went with Mr. Lewty to No. 9, York-terrace, and took the prisoner—I searched him at the station, but I found nothing on him—from Acorn-street to No. 9, York-terrace, is about a mile.
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am an inspector of notes to the Bank of England. These are forgeries, and both from the same plate.
Cross-examined. Q. Are they very good imitations? A. Yes, they are such as might impose upon persons not acquainted with them.
COURT. to EMILY PALMER. Q. Did you receive the rents of this man? A. Yes, for the house in Acorn-street—he had not given any notice to quit there.

JOHN BOND . re-examined. When I found the prisoner at Peekham, he was at his brother's house—his furniture was still at Acorn-street—I had watched the house night and day, and had not seen him—I saw his wife on one occasion—he is a journeyman cooper.
NOT GUILTY .

1069.
RICHARD GOWER was indicted
for embezzlement.
MESSRS. BODKIN. and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY LINN . I am ticket collector in the employ of the South Eastern Railway Company, at Forest Hill, the prisoner was head ticket collector there. On 18th Aug., I collected the tickets at the half past 7 o'clock—Margate train—this is the book—I received from passengers who had no tickets 2l. 2s. 6d.—on the following morning, I paid that to the prisoner, and he signed the book, "Received, Richard Gower"—I saw him sign it.

WILLIAM AKERS LORD . I am a collector of tickets at Forest Hill, in the employ of the South Eastern Railway Company. On 18th Aug., I col
lected the tickets for the half past 7 o'clock Margate train—I received 2l. 7s. from passengers who had no tickets—on the following morning I handed that to the prisoner—it is entered here in my book, and he signed it, "Richard Cower"—"No tickets, 2l."—"No tickets, 7s."—I handed these together—I have the excess book here—it is the duty of the prisoner to enter the sums he receives from the ticket collectors into this book—in the entry of 18th Aug., these two sums are entered—I entered them myself that day, by the prisoner's directions—the entry is "No tickets, Margate, 2l. 7s."—I find here an entry of 2l. 17s. 6d.—that includes the 2l. 2s. 6d., received from Linn—I copied it by his directions from Linn's book—the total amount that day is 10l. 5s. 7d., including those two sums—this book is kept in counterfoil—the counterfoil is kept in the book—the other part is sent up to London—in this account of 18th Aug., I made the entry in the counterfoil—I showed it to the prisoner after it was made—when the duplicate is made out, it is generally given to the prisoner, but if he had left, it was put under cover for him.
COURT. Q. How was it sent? A. It was forwarded by the train, under cover, directed to Mr. Gower, booking office, London Bridge—the duplicate I made out corresponded with the counterfoil.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. What was done with the counterfoil on 18th Aug.? A. It is here in the book—the duplicate, to the best of my belief, was given to the prisoner, but if he were gone, it was sent to him—I do not remember—my attention was called to this matter on the day the prisoner was given into custody—about 17th or 18th Sept, I copied these in the book by desire of the prisoner—this is the company's book, as well as these smaller books—I do not know how long the prisoner has been in the employ of the company—I have been in the service five years—he was in the service when I came.
COURT. Q. Is it his duty to make these entries? A. Yes, but I have often done it by his direction—I believe he used to look at it—I cannot say whether he looked at it on this particular night.

FREDERICK CHATWIN . I am ticket collector of the South Eastern Rail
way, at Forest Hill. On 22nd Aug., I received 4s. and 15s. for passengers by the Reigate train, from persons who had not tickets—I paid that sum to the prisoner on the following morning—I have the book here—these sums are entered in the book—the prisoner signed it when I handed him the money—in the excess book of the next day I made out this account, under the direction of the prisoner—in this counterfoil here is this 4s.1

entered by the 9 o'clock Reigate train, persons with no tickets—the gross amount is 3l. 4s. 6d., that is the amount of the whole day, in addition to writing the counterfoil—I made out the duplicate account, which was sent to London—the duplicate corresponded with the counterfoil exactly—when I made the duplicate, I gave it to the prisoner—I remember that day.

Cross-examined. Q. How often do you copy the account in this book! A. About once a week—some weeks twice—it depended on whether Lord was there or not—when Lord was not there, I did it—this book was intended as a check for the whole—I copied the duplicate and counterfoil of 22nd Aug.—I have a distinct recollection of handing the sheet over to the prisoner—I never sent any, I always handed them to the prisoner—I know I handed it to him that day—he was on the platform—he lives in Tooley-street—he came down by the quarter past 9 o'clock train in the morning—it was in the evening I handed him this account.
MR. BODKIN. Q. What you entered was from the small books into this? A. Yes, and it has the prisoner's signature.

DONALD MUNRO . I am a clerk in the employ of the Brighton Railway Company. This account (Looking at it) is my writing—it is for 2l. 5s. 6d., it is the account of Friday, 22nd Aug.—I wrote it out by the wish of Mr. Gower—he came into the office one morning with his right hand tied up—he said he had got his thumb smashed, and would we be kind enough to write a few lines for him—another clerk and I were in the office—I said, "Certainly," and I wrote this from a slip of paper which he produced—he took the slip of paper away with him—I copied this from the paper and from his dictation, both—he held the piece of paper in his hand and read it out to me—the paper was about the same size as one of these duplicates—I did not observe whether there was any printing on the paper he read it from—the account I wrote was written on a regular form, an excess form—the prisoner gave me that form to write it on—in the account I made out I do not see anything like 4s. for tickets for Reigate—what I made out was 2l. 5s. 6d.—his right hand was tied up with a handkerchief round it.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner produced what you call an excess form, and you wrote on it? A. Yes—he handed it to me—I did not see the paper from which I copied it—he held it in his hand—I might have looked at it—I cannot tell where the excess papers are deposited—I believed his thumb was injured.

CHRISTOPHER EDWARD COCKERTON . I am station clerk at the London Bridge terminus. I should say the prisoner has been in the employ of the company from ten to twelve years—he has been head ticket collector for four or five years past—of late the up trains stop at Forest Hill, and the tickets are taken there—the prisoner had the superintendence of that station—it was his duty, at the close of the day, to fill up a form, and half was for
warded to the London station—that ought to contain all the money received—this counterfoil of 18th Aug. did not come to me—this duplicate came to me as the duplicate of the excess book of 18th Aug.—the duplicates have come to me from Forest Hill by casual persons, in an envelope, generally—the prisoner did not bring them at all himself, they came by the train—by the paper that came on 18th Aug., the amount represented as received is 3l. 0s. 8d.—in the counterfoil of that date, under the head of Margate, here appears 2l. 17s. 6d. and 2l. 7s.—the account of them has not been rendered to me—in the counterfoil of 22nd Aug., the amount is 3l. 4s. 6d., and what was sent up to me was 2l. 5s. 6d.—it reached me in the same way in course of business.

COURT. Q. The amount of the counterfoil of 22nd Aug. is 3l. 4s. 6d., and the paper you received 2l. 5s. 6d.? A. Yes—I am not quite certain when it was discovered that this variance existed—it was about 2nd or 3rd Sept—after this alleged fraud had been discovered, Mr. White, an accountant, came to me, and the prisoner was with him—Mr. White asked him what was the amount which had been rendered by him to the company—it was then found that the counterfoils and the accounts did not agree.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure as to the time that the prisoner has been in the service of the company, is it not as long as thirteen years? A. I have been there twelve years—I think he was there when I came—during the last three months I have occasionally received gross sums on account—on 18th Aug. I did not receive a sum from him—he left it with another person—on 22nd Aug. I received 15l., and there was still a small balance left in his hands—I know that he received the money in small sums from the ticket collectors—the excess forms are always sent up in an envelope—I find them in the letter box, or they are brought in by some of the guards—I have known him some years—I always thought him an honest man.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Was that 15l. on account of moneys he had received? A. Yes—I had no open account with him.

DAVID WHITE . I am an accountant in the employ of the Railway Com
pany. I was sent down to Forest Hill station—I saw the prisoner there—I asked him to give me an account of the discrepancies there were between the counterfoils and the money paid—he said he did not understand it—I showed him the duplicates—he gave me no explanation—he came up to London with me—I took him, first of all, to the booking office, to see Mr. Cockerton, and after that to the general manager's office—the matter was then stated in presence of the prisoner—he was again asked for an expla
nation—we could get nothing more out of him.

Cross-examined. Q. What was the answer he gave? A. "I do not un
derstand you"—I asked him for an explanation—he replied, "I do not un
derstand it"—I pointed out to him the difference between the counterfoil and the returns, and that was what he said at both offices—he came readily with me, and brought the books with him—I went down on a special mission.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you show him this document of 18th Aug? A. That was the one I called his attention to—the difference between that and the counterfoil—I asked him whose writing the duplicate was, he said he did not know—he did not say that was not the return he made.

HENRY DUFF . (policeman, M 219). On 3rd Sept, I took the prisoner into custody—I told him he was charged with embezzling 2l. 17s. 6d., on 18th Aug.—he made no reply to the charge—when at the station he gave me 15l. in gold—one gold coin, 2l. 0s. 10d. in silver, and 1s. 2 1/2 d. in copper—while I was counting it, he said, "I dare say you think it strange that I have got so much money in my pocket, but some of that money belongs to the South Eastern Railway Company," mentioning the name of some person which I did not hear.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you take him? A. At the London Bridge station, I think in one of the directors' offices—he did not say he wanted to pay this money over—he did not say he was ready to pay it over—he said, "I dare say you think it strange that I have got so much money, but some of it belongs to the South Eastern Railway."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY .—
Four Years Penal Servitude.
(The whole amount of the prisoner's embezzlement was stated to be about 200l.)

1070.
HENRY JACKSON
, feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Simon Cassimir, and stealing 11 coats; his goods. (See page 750).
MR. RIBTON. conducted the Prosecution.

SIMON CASSIMIR . (by an interpreter). I live at No. 24, Devonshire-place, Kennington-lane—I have lived there for the last fifteen years—on a day in Aug. I left my house in the morning—I had fastened the doors and left the house in good order—I returned about 1 o'clock, I found the house all in disorder—I had a deal of trouble to open the house door—two men were convicted here last sessions for this same offence.

ELIZABETH REASON . I am single. I live at No. 11, Devonshire-place, Kennington—the prosecutor lives at No. 24, on the same side of the way—on 11th Aug., between 9 and 10 o'clock, I saw the prisoner pass the house—I know he is the same man by the mark on his lip—some time after I saw three men standing by the prosecutor's door—that was a little after 11 o'clock—I saw two men enter the house, and the third man went to the bottom of the street—I am not able to say whether the prisoner was the third man—I went and gave information to the policeman that two men had gone into the house.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. This was on 11th Aug.? A. Yes—I did not see the prisoner till Sept.—it is five weeks to day since I last saw him—I had not seen the man, whoever he was, before—I am able to swear that he is the man that passed my house, but I could not swear that he was one of the three—when I looked out again I saw three men loitering about the street, and I saw three men go to the door—I cannot tell what clothes the man had on that passed—I could not tell whether they were light or dark—I only know that he had a cap on his head—he had whiskers when he passed the house, and when he was at the police court he had not the whiskers—he had a scar on his right lip.
COURT. Q. When you next saw him he was in custody? A. Yes, he was shown to me with three other men, I picked him out.

ANN ROOKE . I am the wife of Michael Rooke. In Aug. I lived it No. 22, next door but one to the prosecutor—in the beginning of Aug. I was at my front window, and I saw three men loitering about—the first time I saw them was about 10 o'clock—I saw them again a little after 11 at the same place—the prisoner is one of the three men—I gave evidence last Aug. against two of the men, who were convicted—I am sure the prisoner was one of the three, I saw him, he went towards the street door—he went to the key hole and looked, and said, "All right, mate"—I was at that time at my window, which was open—I went down stairs—I had something in my hand—I went to the yard and then to the front door, and when I came to the front door I found the two men were in custody—that was about a quarter of an hour afterwards—they were the two men that I had seen with the prisoner—the prisoner was not there—I am quite sure the prisoner is the man—he had whiskers on that day, and there are no whiskers on him now—I saw him at the police court afterwards, he was with one other man, I picked him out of the two.

Cross-examined. Q. You had never seen this man before? A. No—I did not take particular notice of his clothes—I noticed his features—I do not remember what coloured clothes he had on, whether they were dark or light—the police constable came to me after the last trial, and asked if I could identify the third man—I said I could—he told me he had a man in custody—the prisoner was shown to me at the court in a room—I went in the room with the officer—the prisoner and another man were
standing together—the Other man was much about the same height as he is—the other man was a little taller—the other man had whiskers.

SARAH ANN FOX . On 11th Aug. I was passing down Devonshire place, Kennington—I saw three men standing at the door of No. 24, they were doing nothing, but they were in conversation—the prisoner was one—I can speak to him by the cut on his lip—I was weak and ill, and had occasion to rest myself—I stopped, and was looking at him for about five minutes—I was not three yards from him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to identify the man? A. Yes; he was in the open court with five or six men—they were not policemen, but men that were in prison—I did not give a description of this man—I was not examined here at the last—I did not give a description of the man till I went to the police court—he had bushy whiskers, I was passing down the street, and stopped to rest—I was going with my husband's dinner—I had a baby in my arms—I cannot tell what kind of clothes the man had on—I did not take notice of the clothes—I looked at the prisoner's features—he had a lightish coat—I did not take notice of his trowsers—he had a cap on—I could not tell whether it was dark or light.
ANN ROOKE . re-examined. The right side of the prisoner's face was next to me when he was looking at the key hole—I did not observe the cut on his lip.

GUILTY . ** Aged 30.—
Six Years Penal Servitude.

1071.
JOHN BREEM
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Joseph Willis, at Wandsworth, and stealing therein 1 shawl, 1 coat, 2 frocks, and other articles; value 2l. 8s.,: his property.

HENRY DENYER . (policeman, V 169). On, Saturday morning, 11th Oct, about a quarter past 1 o'clock, I was on duty in High-street, Wandsworth—I saw the prisoner coming in a direction from the prosecutor's house, about twenty yards from it, carrying a bundle—I asked him what he had got there—he said a bundle, which his b—gal gave him—I saw no girl about the place—I took him to the station—the bundle contained a coat, a shawl, thirteen napkins, two shaets, two frocks, and two pinafores.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me before that? A. I saw you about 12 o'clock—you were then drunk—you were not drunk when I took you—I asked you where the girl was, and you said that you did not know.

JAMES WILLIS . I live in James-yard, High-street, Wandsworth. These articles are my property—I fastened up the house at half past 10 o'clock—I bolted the door—I got up next morning at about a quarter past 6 o'clock—I missed my coat, but thinking some of my family had moved it, I went to my employment—the window was closed, and the shutters pulled to, the same as I had left them—the articles had been left on the sofa in the front parlour—the centre bolt of the window was fastened over night, but there was no drop bolt, and it could be pulled open from outside—I opened the shutters in the morning—I did not observe that the middle bolt had been, pulled out.

Prisoner's Defence. I received 17s. that night, and got drinking with my mates, and got rather intoxicated; I met a friend with the bundle; she told me to lay hold of it for a few minutes, and she would not keep me long; I did not go five yards; the policeman came up, and asked me where I got them; I said, "From a gal "Where is she?" says he; "I do not know," say I, and he took me.
NOT GUILTY .

1072.
HENRY HARRIS and
THOMAS BECKETT
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Jane Harris, at St. Mary, New
ington, and stealing therein 1 desk, 4 spoons, 1 violincello, and other articles, value 19l. 19s.; her property: to which

HARRIS
PLEADED GUILTY . ** Aged 21.—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

BECKETT
PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1073.
WILLIAM JONES
, stealing in the dwelling house of
James Selby, at Lambeth, 1 watch, value 3l. his property, and afterwards bur
glariously breaking out of the said dwelling house: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Confined Six Months.

1074.
JANE WHITE
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Ann Fel
stead, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.
MR. DOYLE. conducted the Prosecution.

ANN FELSTEAD . I am a widow, and live at No. 95, Granby-street, Wa
terloo-road, the prisoner lives at No. 93, next door but one. On 22nd Oct, between 10 and 11 o'clock at night, I went out for a pint of half and half—as I passed her window she muttered something, I cannot say what—as I came back she struck me on the temple, and said, "Take that, you old cow, for going up against the people at No. 3"—(I had had to bind them over to keep the peace at No. 3, as they were always insulting me)—I was cut, and the blood flowed very much.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Have yotf ever been bound over to keep the peace yourself? A. No—it is not one of the most respectable loca
lities—I have known the prisoner some time, she has lodged with me, and has had twelve months in prison—we never had quarrels—I have never been taken to a police court on a charge of assaulting her—there was not a row in my house about a month or six weeks before this occurred, nor did the police come—I was obliged to go to the police court, because a person who frequented the prisoner's house came over to mine—there was a little bit of jealousy and she challenged her to fight—she would not do so, and she broke all my windows—I was in the street, and the prisoner reached out at the window—I did not lay hold of the cape of her dress and ask her who stole the clock, and spit in her face—Jonathan Adams is her landlord—the police sergeant refused to take the prisoner because he did not see the blow struck—he did not tell me I had no right to go and annoy the woman in her own room—I have kept the house seventeen or eighteen year's—it is a common house.

MARGARET GORDON . I am single, and live at No. 2, Granby-street. On the night of 2nd Oct. I saw the prosecutrix pass No. 93, where the prisoner lives, on her way to the public house—the prisoner was at the window, and said, "There goes that fat old cow; I will kill her"—she had some sharp instru
ment in her hand; I think it was a pair of scissors, or a penknife—as the prosecutrix returned she said, "You went against the people at No. 3, did you; take that, you old cow!"—she struck her with the instrument in her hand, and blood flowed immediately.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see it? A. Yes, but I did not see the handle; I saw a bit of steel, with a very sharp point.

MARY ANN EDWARDS . I am single. I was standing talking to the last witness, and saw the prisoner with some sharp instrument in her hand, like a pair of scissors, knocking it on the window ledge, and threatening Mrs. Felstead—it shone—as Mrs. Felstead came back, the prisoner leant out out over
the window, and struck her—I saw something in her hand at that time, and afterwards too—Mrs. Felstead had done nothing to her, but she said, "Oh, my God, I am stabbed!"

MATTHEW FRENCH WAQSTAFF . I am surgeon to the polite force. Mrs. Felstead was brought to me on the following day by the police, by order of the Magistrate—I found a triangular puncture, but did not probe it, as it was healing—a pair of scissors or a penknife would be likely to do it.
Cross-examined. Q. Might it have been done if a triangular piece of a jug was thrown at her? A. If it was the same shape, but I think there would be more bruise—a penny piece would not do it.
GUILTY . ** Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutries.

(Sergeant Hughes stated that the prisoner had been most of her time in prison for the last nine or ten years).—
Confined Three Months.

1075.
THOMAS BATTERSBY
, feloniously forging and uttering a re
ceipt for 5s.; also, a receipt for 8*.; with intent to defraud: to both which he

p.rs: PLEADED GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
1076.
GEORGE JOHNSON,
WILLIAM HOLLOWAY , and
CHARLES HOPKINS
, unlawfully obtaining 2s., the money of
George Bolton, by false pretences.—2nd COUNT, Conspiring to defraud him of his roods.
MR. LILLEY. conducted the Prosecution.

HARRIETT BOLTON . I am the mother of George Bolton, who keeps the Victoria public house at Deptford. On Friday afternoon, 3rd Oct., the three prisoners came together, and the barmaid brought me a sovereign to change—(we have change constantly ready on Fridays)—I went into the bar parlour, got the change, put it on the counter, and said to Johnson, "There is your change"—it was four half crowns and two five shilling pieces—I am certain it was quite right—I turned to the barmaid, and said, "What is to be taken?"—she said, "A pint of ale"—Johnson then said, "My dear lady, you have given me half a crown short"—I said, "I am satisfied I gave you the full change; I gave you four half crowns"—he said, "You see heve is hut three"—I gave him 2s. 3d. in addition, and said, "There is the half crown, but you have done me out of half a crown"—they then wanted a pint of ale and some bread and cheese, but I said, "No, I will not serve you with anything more"—Holloway said to Johnson, "You owe me 5s. and Johnson said, "Now I have got change I will pay you"—I am sure they are the men—they were in the bar more than a quarter of an hour.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Q. Do you keep a good deal of silver in heaps? A. I had only two parcels of silver—two separate 10s. worths; five two shilling pieces, and four half crowns—there was nothing more there, and I had counted that not five minutes before—there had been 10l. worth of silver on the waiter that day—the heaps were very close together, but there were none then.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Did you count it as you laid it down? A. Yes, and it was right—it was my son's money—I did not believe that I had given him half a crown short, but I gave him the 2s. 3d. to get rid of him and have done with it; I thought that was best.

JOSEPH BENJAMIN LITHWORTH . I keep the China Hall public house, at Deptford. On 3rd Oct., between 1 and 2 o'clock, I saw the prisoners about thirty yards from my house together, about half a mile from the Victoria—Hopkins

left the others, and went into my house—he wanted to know whether I could not give him change for 1l. worth of silver—I did not give it to him; the silver was given back to him, and he disputed it being 1s. short—he thenjwent out and joined the other two; they went away together and I followed them to about eight houses—sometimes one of them went in, and sometimes another—after they had been into a baker's shop I went in and heard what had passed—they were given into custody about an hour afterwards at the Gibraltar public house, about a mile and a half from my house, three quarters of a mile from the Victoria—I had seen them go into Mr. Bolton's, and into Mr. Lambert's, a baker's.
Cross-examined. Q. Who gave them into custody? A. A person named Kiddey, for trying to do people out of money.
MR. LILLEY. Q. Who went into Mr. Holman's, the Plough? A. I saw Hopkins waiting outside while the other two went in.

JANE HOLMAN . I am the wife of Benjamin Holman, of the Plough tavern, Rotherhithe. On 3rd Oct., about 2 o'clock, Johnson and Hollowly came for 1 1/2 d. worth of bitters and a glass of 6d. ale—(MR. LEWIS. objected to this evidence, it being the subject of another indictment. The COURT. having consulted MR. JUSTICE ERLE, decided that the evidence was admissible, but within certain limits)—one of them, I did not see which, laid down a sovereign—I went into the bar parlour, and brought out four half crowm, nine shillings and two sixpences, put one of the sixpences into the till, and took 3d. out, which made their change right—I laid it down, and was in the act of turning away, when Johnson said, "This is not right, here is but 7s. 6d. here"—I said, "I am certain I gave you 9s. 6d."—he said, "There is but 7s. 6d. here"—I said, "I see that, but I am positive I gave you 9s. 6d.," and then opened my till and gave him two more shillings, as I did not want a piece of work.
Cross-examined. Q. At the time you gave the extra two shillings did you or did you not believe that you had given the two shillings previously? A. I believed I had given it right.

GEORGE CADWELL . (policeman, R 189). On 3rd Oct. I took the prisoners at a public house just by the Gibraltar gate, Deptford. They were given in charge by Mr. Holman—I found on Hopkins four half crowns and five 2s. pieces nothing on Holloway, and eight shillings and two halfpence on Johnson.

(MR. LEWIS, on behalf of Johnson, submitted that as to the fast Count, there was no false pretence, as the prosecutor parted with the money knowingly, and that there was no evidence of a conspiracy to defraud Mrs. Bolton. The COURT. considered that it was a case for the Jury.)
Holloway's Defence. I met Johnson, and asked him for 8s. which he owed me; I went into the public house, and he paid me; I was gambling with him afterwards, and he won it back again.

Hopkins's Defence. I met Johnson, and got drinking with him; he got tossing and gambling; a sovereign was changed two or three times, and as I won it, I got gold for it, not intending to gamble any more.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY. * on both COUNTS . Aged 40.

HOLLOWAY—
GUILTY. * on 2nd COUNT . Aged 28.

HOPKINS—
GUILTY. on 2nd COUNT . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1077.
GEORGE JOHNSON,
WILLIAM HOLLOWAY , and
CHARLES HOPKINS
were again iadicted for stealing 2s., the money of
Samuel Holman.
MR. LILLEY. offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1078.
TIMOTHY JONES
, stealing, on 7th Oct, whilst employed in the Post Office, a post letter containing 48 postage stamps; also, on 15th Oct., a post letter containing 1 sovereign, 1 half sovereign, and 6d., the property of
