Her Majesty's Postmaster General: to both which he

PLEADED GUILTY .—
Six Years Penal Servitude.

1079.
JOHN STANLEY
feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged 5l. note, with intent to defraud.
MR. GIFFARD. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM FAWCETT . I am a carpenter and builder, at Bermondsey. On 8th Oct, between 11 and 12 o'clock in the day, the prisoner came and asked the price of laths—I told him—he said he should want between fire and six loads next week, but he had repairs at Dockhead and wanted half a load at once—he purchased half a load, and gave me a 5l. note in payment—I gave him 4l. 2s. 6d. change—he said he was building some houses in the London-road—I asked him in what part, he said it was the second turning on the left hand side, leading from the Kent-road—he said he would send for the laths next day, but he did not until the day after—I asked him to write his name on the note, and saw him write, "Mr. Clark"—he omitted patting the address, I reminded him of it, and he gave it me, and I put it down as he stated, "Westmoreland-road, Newington"—this is the note (produced)—I put my initials to it—I afterwards paid the note away, and it was returned to me stamped "forged"—that same day the prisoner called again, and said he wanted to see me about some more laths—I asked him what quantity he wanted—he said about a load, and he would call in the morning, and pay me for them—I told him that I could not find any person out of the name that he had written on the note, neither could I find out any buildings like those he described—he said he was right, and I must be mistaken—he seemed a little surprised and confused—I then told him that he had passed a bad note to me—he did not make any particular answer farther than he would take me to the person he had taken it of—I had a friend (Mr. Frost) in the house, because the prisoner had sent word that he was going to call, and I was prepared for him—he could not give any satisfactory account of himself, and I gave him in charge.

Prisoner. Q. When I came to your yard the first morning with the note, did not you recognise me directly as coming to your place for five or six years, day after day, and week after week, when I was working for Mr. lindsell, the builder in the Kent-road? A. No; I did not ask if your name was Stanley, and say I thought I knew your face—I had no knowledge of you, no more than if I had never seen you—I did not know your name was Stanley—every word you have said is false—when I asked you to put your name to the note, you did not say, "Shall I put my own name or the name of Clark, the man'sthat sent me with it"—nor did I say, "You had better put the name the note belongs to," you told me your name was Clark, and you and your father were building these houses—I wish to be particular, I did not know you when you came, but since then I find I had a knowledge of you—I do not know who fetched the laths away—they were fetched away when there was nobody in the yard—when I asked you whether you had given your right name and address, you inquired why I asked you such a question as that, and I said, "I may as well tell you at once, the note that you gave me is a forged note"—you said you took it of your fether—the only

persons you mentioned respecting the note were yourself and your father—no other name whatever—you asked me to go with you to the person you took it of—but I said no, I was not satisfied with the information you gave me respecting it, and I should leave you in charge of my friend while I fetched a policeman.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. You say 'you do remember now that you had seen him before; when and where? A. I stated that I had a recollection of him, since this occurred, of his working for a person named Lindsell, a plasterer, in the Kent-road, but that must be eight years ago—he was quite a young lad then.

JAMES FROST . I am a bricklayer. On 15th Oct. I was in Mr. Fawcett's house—he requested me to take care of the prisoner while he went to fetch a policeman—while he was gone, the prisoner asked me if the note was a forged one—I said I believed so, he would hear further of it—I asked him if he had been building any houses in the neighbourhood—he said "Yes"—I asked where—he said, "Against the Elephant and Castle"—I asked him what street there—he said he did not exactly know the street—he said, "Then it is a forged note"—I said, "Yes, have you got the money with you to pay for itr—he said no, he had not, but no doubt he could get it if I went with him—I asked if he knew where he got the note—he said, yes, he took it of a gentleman—I said, "Did the gentleman make you a present of it f—he said, no, but he paid it to him for work he had done for him as a plasterer.

Prisoner. Q. You asked me what I was by trade; I told you I was a bricklayer and plasterer, did I not? A. No; I asked if you had been building houses in the neighbourhood, and you said, "Yes"—you did not say you had been plastering the houses there—you said you could no doubt find the man that gave you the note, if I came with you—I said no, I would give you in charge.

JAMES THOMPSON . (policernan, M 204). I took the prisoner into custody—I charged him with uttering a forged note on the 9th—he said, "I did not know it was forged till now; I stood on Newington-causeway one day last week; some gentleman asked if I wanted any work; I said I did; he gave me the 5l. note to get some laths, and as I knew Mr. Fawcett, I went to him for the laths"—he said the gentleman told him that his name was Clark, and that he lived at 31 or 32, Westmoreland-road, Newington—(there is no such number there)—he said the gentleman had told him he would remain there till he came back with the change, and when he left Mr. Fawcett's, he returned and gave the gentleman the change—on the way to the police court next morning, he pulled his trowsers down and said, "Here, I have got my working trowsers on now"—I said, "Yes, it is a strange thing you did not say so last night"—he said, "Oh, it don't matter, for I have nothing on I care about"—I did not search him.

ROBERT CLARK . I am a carpenter and joiner, at No. 20, Westmoreland-road, Walworth. I know nothing of the prisoner—I never saw him that I know of—I never gave him a 5l. note, or sent him to buy laths at Mr. Fawcett's—I do not know whether there is any other person of my names living in Westmoreland-road.
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am an inspector of notes at the Bank of England, This note is a forgery.

(The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "The gentleman gave the 5l. to order some laths for him; he told me to go to Mr. Fawcett, in the Grange-road; he told me his name was Mr. Clark, of Westmoreland-place, Marylebone; I went to Mr. Fawcett, and ordered half

a load of laths, and paid him the note; he asked me my name, and I said, Which shall I put, my own name, or the name of the man who sent me?" he said, 'The name of the person who sent yon,' and I wrote 'Mr. Clark;' Mr. Fawcett gave me the change, and I met the gentleman in the New Kent-road, and gave him the money; he said I was to meet him next morning at the house of call, and he would give me work; I went, but he did not come; on the 15th I met the same gentleman, who wished me to order more laths, and he said he would call and settle next day; I went, sod was given into custody.")
(The prisoner, in his defence, repeated in substance the tame statement as above.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

1080.
ANN PRITCHARD
, burglary in the dwelling house of
Elizabeth Skinner, and stealing therein 4 table cloths, 1 sheet, and other articles; her property: and
JOHN PRITCHARD
, feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen.

ELIZABETH SKINNER . I am a widow, and take in mangling, at No. 4, Bridge-road, Battersea, I rent a house, and have some lodgers; Mrs. Alcroft occupies the back parlour adjoining the room where I mangle—I the mangling room fronts the street—the room is entered by a door on the left of the passage from the street door—there is a string through the street door from the latch, so that it can be opened from the outside—on Wed
nesday evening, the 15th of this month, I left home a little after 8 o'clock—I locked the mangling room door, and took the key with me—I returned a little before 11 o'clock—I found the street door open—it appeared as though it bad given way to a sudden jerk—I found a night dress under my feet the minute I opened the door—I picked it up, and then looked to the basket, which I left full, and found nearly all the things missing—there were six chemises, four table cloths, a lot of children's things, a night dress, and several other articles—I know the female prisoner—she had been in my mangling room that afternoon—she is not a friend of mine—she came in to know whether a next door neighbour was there; and then the party sitting there asked her to drink out of the pot she was drinking out of-these (produced) are a portion of the articles I missed—I know the male prisoner by sight—he and his wife live near me.

Ann Pritchard. I followed her to the public house, and cautioned her about leaving the door open. Witness. About half past 1 o'clock she came in where I was at the beer shop—she said, "Mrs. Skinner, I have been at your house, your door is open, and you will lose your linen—I then went back, and found both the doors were open.

CHARLES SIMPKIN . (policeman, 120.) I received some information from the last witness, on the morning of 16th, at about 6 o'clock, in consequence of which I went to the prisoner's house, No. 0, Europa-place, about one hundred yards from the prosecutrix's—I saw Mrs. Pritcbard—I told her she was to consider herself in custody for stealing a lot of linen, the pro
perty of Mrs. Skinner—she said she knew nothing at all about it—I then told her I should search the place—in searching her room I found a small portion of the things—I then made a further search in a box up stairs, and found the remainder; all of them that were stolen—when I found the second lot, she said, "Oh, my good Lord!" and threw up her hands—I examined the lock of Mrs. Skinner's mangling room—I found the lock had been forced away from the wood work, by pushing.

JAMES WRIGHT . (policeman, W 294). I was with the last witness and took the female prisoner to the station house—she told me it was a very bad job, and the effects of beer that caused her to do so—she said she had taken the things out of a lark, and it was her intention to take them back to Mrs. Skinner the next morning—she did not tell me she was with Mrs. Skinner from 1 to 4 o'clock.

SARAH ALCROFT . I lodge at Mrs. Skinner's, and occupy the back room. I returned home at about 9 or half past 9 o'clock on the evening in question—the clock was half an hour fast—it was half past 9 by the clock, so it was 9 o'clock—when I went in, the door was open—I went straight through into my back room to get a candle—I saw Mrs. Pritchard, and she asked me how I was—she was in the mangling room, standing at the right hand side of the room—she had got a small bundle underneath her cloak—she asked me how the baby was—I told her as well as I could expect—I took a light and went into my own room—I heard her in the mangling room—after that I saw Mrs. Pritchard pass round the mangle on to the left hand side, and take a bundle out of the clothes basket—it was either in the door way or on the table, I cannot swear which—I heard a voice say, "Hold up your right hand"—it seemed to me like a man's voice—there was a very heavy footstep, but I could not say whether it was a man or another woman, because the window would not allow me to see—they did not remain there long after that—I gave information to Mrs. Skinner the next morning.

Q. Did you know Mrs. Skinner was not there? A. I do not know any
thing about Mrs. Skinner's affairs—I had been out all day in the country, and had just returned home—I did not know whether she had had any company—I told her what I saw when she told me of the robbery.

STEPHEN SYMONS . (policemcm, V 306). On the night of the robbery I was in the neighbourhood of the prosecutrix's house—about fifty yards off I saw Mr. Pritchard—he was walking from Mrs. Skinner's house—he came up towards me, and said, "Policeman, I think there is something up there, and if you will go with me, I will show you"—I went to the back of some houses—he said, "If you go round to Europa-place, No. 5, I will show you some one; some one has been attempting to steal some brass taps and some lead pipe from some water butts"—he went one way and I the other, and I met him at his door—he took me into the back place and showed me a place as if somebody had given the pipe a blow—he said his wife had seen somebody there the night previous—I was away about a quarter of an hour—I discovered afterwards that the room at Mrs. Skinner's had been robbed.
John Pritchard. It is perfectly true what he has stated about the cistern and the water pipe; this was at a quarter past 8 o'clock. Witness. The clock had struck nine; I was on early duty.
(The prisoner, Ann Pritchard, in her defence, stated that she had been drinking with the prosecutrix, and merely took the things in a lark in order to frighten her.)
John Pritchard's Defence. I am as innocent as God in heaven; I did not know of the affair till ten hours after.

JOHN PRITCHARD.—
NOT GUILTY .

ANN PRITCHARD.—
GUILTY . *—Aged 38.—
Confined Six Months.

1081.
ANN BASSETT was indicted
for a robbery with violence, on
Susan Abrahams, and stealing from her 1 half crown and 1 penny, of her moneys.
SUSAN ABRAHAMS . I live with my mother, in James's-street, New Cut,

Lambeth. On 22d Sept, I was going into the gallery entrance of the Victoria Theatre—the prisoner was standing outside—she asked me for a drop of gin—I refused—she called two girls, and they dragged me to the Victoria stairs—one of them put her hand over my mouth, and half a crown and a penny fell out of my pocket—I saw the prisoner pick it up—a con
stable then came—I did not lose sight of her—I saw her go right up the road—I did not follow her—the constable took her into custody.

GEORGE LOCKETT . I am a shoemaker, living at No. 4, John's place. I was At the Victoria Theatre on the night in question—I saw the prisoner pick up half a crown—I saw the last witness dragged into the theatre—I know nothing of the persons who did it—there were two or three girls—the prisoner was standing up against the side of the gallery—I saw her take np the money—she vent towards the Victoria Tavern—I saw her after
wards taken into custody.
JAMES BRADLEY . (policeman, L 93). I took the prisoner into custody—she was not sober—she had been about the Victoria Theatre for an hour and a half previous to that. Witness for the Defence.

CATHERINE CONWAY . I was at the Victoria Theatre on the night in question, with my basket—I saw Mrs. Bassett come, and she asked me, did I see her old man—she was running up stairs, hallooing out for her hus
band—a policeman went up stairs, and she came down with him, and he told her to go outside the door—two girls came up to this young girl (the prosecutrix), and asked her if she would stand a quartern of gin, she said no, she had no money—she was fumbling with the money, and she dropped the half crown down on the floor—sbe made a reach to pick it up, and she could not; one of the girls, with a cloak on, came and shoved her, and this young man (Lockett) came along with her, and picked it up—I said, "Why do you not give her in charge?"—the prisoner went outside the door—she was given in charge—the young man made a grab at the mo
ney, and said, "If I was her I should give you in charge"—he said, "I thought I could get it to give it to the owner"—the prisoner was out
side the gallery door when the other two girls shoved the prosecutrix—she did not take any part in pulling her into the gallery door—it was the girl that had the cloak on that picked up the half crown.

GEORGE LOCKETT . re-examined. I saw the half crown down—I did not try to pick it up—I was there accidentally—I know none of the parties who were there—I am quite sure the prisoner is the woman who picked it up—she went away towards the Victoria Tavern—a policeman came up, and she was given in charge—that is what I saw.

SUSAN ABRAHAM . re-examined. I saw the prisoner pick up the half crown—it was knocked out of my hand—she was one of them that did it—she said "Give me a penny, I have got a penny, to get a half quartern of gin"—it is quite false what the witness Con way has said, because it is quite round the corner whdre she was—I dropped the money inside the stairs.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Two Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER. 24TH, 1856.
